Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Situation2: There is a plan to have a quiet ten-minute window.
Story: I stare at my phone, heart pounding. My friend’s message is sharp, wounded—she’s misunderstood my joke, and now she thinks I’m upset with her. I know I should call her right away, clear things up before the hurt grows. That’s what a good friend does: communicate, don’t let misunderstandings fester. But I also see the time. In just a minute, I’m supposed to begin my daily meditation, a quiet ten-minute window I promised myself I’d never skip. As a Buddhist, I know how important it is to keep this commitment, to practice mindfulness and not let the world’s noise pull me away. My mind tugs in two directions—one voice urging me to pick up the phone, the other whispering to sit, breathe, and let go. I feel the tension in my chest, the guilt of possibly letting my friend down, the anxiety of breaking my own spiritual promise. I close my eyes, torn, the phone heavy in my hand, the silence pressing in.
